title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for enhanced border investigative resources on the Southwest border, including funds for salaries, expenses, and equipment for the United States Customs Service. This includes specific allocations for technology deployment such as mobile truck gamma ray systems and high energy pallet gamma ray systems. The authorization of appropriations includes funding for various technology deployments along the Southwest border, such as mobile truck gamma ray systems, high energy pallet gamma ray systems, higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, canine kennel construction, replacement of canines, and contraband detection kits. The funding allocation includes $2,500,000 for x-ray vans, $1,500,000 for tool trucks, $3,500,000 for refurbishing existing vehicles, $600,000 for contraband detection kits, $1,000,000 for surveillance camera systems, $2,500,000 for truck license plate readers, $1,600,000 for narcotics detectors, $14,800,000 for vehicle targeting systems, $3,000,000 for under vehicle inspection systems, $1,500,000 for passenger facilities, $1,500,000 for work station replacements, $3,500,000 for Customs Automated Operations System, $5,800,000 for explosive detectors, $420,000 for radiation detectors, $720,000 for radiation identification devices, and $180,000 for detection equipment. In addition to previous allocations, $15,832,000 is designated annually for equipment maintenance and personnel training. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds for technologically superior equipment beyond specified items. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds for equipment other than specified items if it is technologically superior and cost-effective. They can also reallocate funds within certain limits for equipment specified in other paragraphs. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment specified in different paragraphs, not exceeding 10% of the amount. $79,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $172,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 will be allocated for increasing personnel at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times and combat drug smuggling. $230,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and 2003 will be used for Ports of Entry infrastructure improvement. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, funds will be allocated for increasing personnel at the Southwest border to combat drug smuggling and reduce waiting times. Additionally, $230,000,000 in each fiscal year will be used for Ports of Entry infrastructure improvement on the Southwest Border. Amounts authorized for the United States Customs Service are in addition to any other appropriations by law.
